title: A Region of UNC-89 (obscurin) Lying Between Two Protein Kinase Domains is a Highly Elastic Spring Required for Proper Sarcomere Organization
background: UNC-89 in C. elegans is a giant muscle protein homologous to mammalian obscurin, localized to sarcomere M-lines and essential for muscle organization. The interkinase (IK) region between two protein kinase domains has low sequence complexity and high proline content, suggesting elastic properties similar to titin's spring elements.
objective: To characterize the biophysical properties of UNC-89's interkinase region and determine its functional role in sarcomere organization using single molecule force spectroscopy and CRISPR/Cas9-generated mutants.
methods: Single molecule force spectroscopy, CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing, immunofluorescence microscopy, structured illumination microscopy, circular dichroism, nematode locomotion assays (swimming/crawling), NemaFlex muscle force measurements, polarized light microscopy.
results: The 571-residue IK region behaves as an entropic spring with random coil properties. Deletion causes severe sarcomere disorganization, extra short A-bands near outer membrane, reduced locomotion (15% swimming, 30% crawling reduction), and impaired muscle force generation. HA-tagging alone reduces UNC-89 expression by ~50% and causes pharyngeal defects.
conclusion: The interkinase region of UNC-89 functions as a highly elastic spring essential for proper sarcomere organization and muscle function, with implications for understanding muscle elasticity mechanisms conserved across species.

learning_notes.note: The 571-residue interkinase region of UNC-89 displays entropic spring behavior with a mean contour length of 186±3 nm when measured by single molecule force spectroscopy, matching the expected 194 nm for a fully extended random coil polypeptide. This elastic property is crucial for maintaining sarcomere integrity under mechanical stress.

CRISPR/Cas9-generated worms with in-frame deletion of the IK region show severe sarcomere disorganization with extra, short A-bands located near the outer muscle cell membrane. These partial A-bands don't extend as deeply into the cell as normal A-bands, indicating defective sarcomere assembly or stability.

Functional consequences of IK deletion include 15% reduction in swimming speed, 30% reduction in crawling speed, and significantly impaired muscle force generation as measured by NemaFlex. This demonstrates the critical role of molecular elasticity in overall muscle performance.

Unexpectedly, simply adding an HA tag to UNC-89's N-terminus reduced giant isoform expression by approximately 50% and caused pharyngeal muscle defects despite normal body wall muscle organization. This highlights the sensitivity of muscle proteins to structural modifications.

The study reveals that all unc-89 mutants with defective pharynxes have smaller body diameters and reduced muscle force, suggesting nutritional deficiencies from impaired feeding may indirectly affect muscle function through metabolic limitations.

Super-resolution microscopy showed that IK deletion disrupts the parallel arrangement of A-bands and creates fragmented sarcomeric structures. The elasticity provided by the IK region appears essential for maintaining proper spacing and registration of contractile elements.

Circular dichroism analysis confirmed the random coil nature of the IK region, showing 16% β-strand, 29% α-helix, and 55% random coil content, consistent with its function as an elastic element that can unfold under mechanical stress.
